physicalObject: wireless game controller with grey digital camouflage pattern
proxyLocation: top-left of snapshot 1, lying flat on the tabletop
utilizationMethod: Grip the right-hand horn of the controller as if it were the mug’s wooden rod-handle: slide the index and middle fingers between the underside of the horn and the main body while the thumb wraps over the top. The larger mass of the controller body now sits forward of the grip point, providing a noticeable forward torque when you lift and tilt—similar to the virtual mug’s offset centre of mass.

virtualObjectInfo.usage: This mug serves as a drinking vessel, designed to be grasped by the handle
virtualObjectInfo.inertia: User should feel the center of mass located significantly forward from the handle grip point
virtualObjectInfo.outline: User should feel a relatively thin, slender rod approximately 2 cm in diameter. User should sense the handle's curved arc and rounded cross-section.
virtualObjectInfo.interactionDeduction: Users will insert their fingers between the mug body and the slender wooden rod-handle, then curl the fingers and thumb into a small power-pinch/pistol grip around the 2 cm-diameter rod. The wrist rotates the mug about the handle’s long axis to lift it off a surface, bring it toward the mouth, and tilt it so liquid pours out. Because the mug’s center of mass sits several centimetres forward of the grip point, the user feels a constant forward torque that must be countered by forearm pronation. Typical motion sequence: reach → grasp handle with C-shaped hand → elbow flexion to raise → wrist supination/pronation to adjust tilt → brief static hold while ‘drinking’ → lower and release. The mug itself offers little compliance; it feels rigid and maintains its cylindrical outline, but its inertia is clearly felt as the weight shifts farther from the wrist when tilted.

physicalObject: matte black stainless steel water bottle with Tesla logo
utilizationMethod: Hold the bottle horizontally by pinching the narrow neck just below the cap with a C-shaped hand. The thick cylindrical body projects forward like the mug, so when you raise and rotate the wrist, the bottle’s weight produces the same forward-pulling inertia you would feel from a full wooden tankard.

physicalObject: small grey 3D-printed rabbit figurine
proxyLocation: top-right of snapshot 1, near the back edge
utilizationMethod: Pinch one of the rabbit’s upright ears between thumb and curled index finger; the ear’s ~1–2 cm thickness mimics a slender handle while the bulk of the body hangs in front of the grip, giving a subtle forward moment that must be countered—echoing the mug’s feel.

physicalObject: individually wrapped rectangular cracker snack
utilizationMethod: Curl the fingers around one short edge of the packet and let the rest of the cracker extend outward. Although light, the rectangular mass projects beyond the pinch point so that lifting and tilting still gives some sense of an offset load, letting users rehearse the reach-grasp-tilt sequence.

physicalObject: yellow tube of UHU all-purpose adhesive glue
utilizationMethod: Grasp only the black plastic cap between thumb and two fingers; the soft metal tube hangs down like a mug body in front of a small cylindrical handle (~2 cm diameter). Rotating the wrist to ‘pour’ makes the tube flop forward under gravity, reproducing the mug’s off-axis inertia.

physicalObject: empty yellow McCafé paper cup
utilizationMethod: Hook the index finger inside the rim while the thumb rests on the outer wall, creating a loop similar to a mug handle. With the cup held sideways, most of its (admittedly light) mass sits ahead of the grip so the user still practises the same lift-and-tilt motion.

physicalObject: black and silver telescoping selfie stick with phone clamp
utilizationMethod: Keep the stick collapsed and grip the phone clamp jaws as a 2 cm-thick handle; the aluminium shaft and plastic grip extend forward as the mug body. Lifting by the clamp makes the forward mass clearly felt, matching the mug’s inertia and allowing natural tilt control.

physicalObject: wireless game controller with grey digital camouflage pattern
proxyLocation: lying near the top-left area of the white tabletop
utilizationMethod: Grip the controller by one of its hand-grips so that the bulk of the controller body sits above your fist. Swing your arm in a chopping motion; the asymmetrical weight distribution (bulkier body vs. thinner grip) gives a mild head-heavy feel similar to a very short-handled hatchet.

virtualObjectInfo.usage: This axe serves as a chopping tool
virtualObjectInfo.inertia: User should feel significant mass with pronounced head-heavy inertia.
virtualObjectInfo.outline: User should feel a cylindrical and substantial grip that requires a firm grasp around the handle's circumference.
virtualObjectInfo.interactionDeduction: Users adopt a full power grip: all fingers wrap around the wooden shaft, thumb closes over the index finger, and the handle rests diagonally across the palm. Most will grasp close to the butt end to maximize swing leverage. Interaction involves large-amplitude shoulder and elbow motion—raising the axe overhead or to the side, then accelerating it through a chopping arc generated by trunk rotation and elbow extension. The head-heavy inertia causes a pronounced lag at swing initiation and strong momentum at follow-through, which the user must dampen with wrist flexors when stopping. Secondary manipulation includes minor wrist roll for aim adjustment and two-handed grips for heavier chops. The virtual axe gives the sensation of a concentrated mass at the far end; once the impact animation plays, the haptic expectation is a sudden stop and vibration through the handle, after which the user relaxes grip pressure to reset.

physicalObject: matte black stainless steel water bottle with Tesla logo
proxyLocation: upright at the top-center of the white tabletop
utilizationMethod: Hold the bottle near its narrow base so that most of its mass extends forward. This provides a cylindrical handle and noticeable top-heavy inertia; performing an overhead or side swing reproduces the lag of an axe head and the momentum during follow-through.

virtualObjectInfo.usage: This axe serves as a chopping tool
virtualObjectInfo.inertia: User should feel significant mass with pronounced head-heavy inertia.
virtualObjectInfo.outline: User should feel a cylindrical and substantial grip that requires a firm grasp around the handle's circumference.
virtualObjectInfo.interactionDeduction: Users adopt a full power grip: all fingers wrap around the wooden shaft, thumb closes over the index finger, and the handle rests diagonally across the palm. Most will grasp close to the butt end to maximize swing leverage. Interaction involves large-amplitude shoulder and elbow motion—raising the axe overhead or to the side, then accelerating it through a chopping arc generated by trunk rotation and elbow extension. The head-heavy inertia causes a pronounced lag at swing initiation and strong momentum at follow-through, which the user must dampen with wrist flexors when stopping. Secondary manipulation includes minor wrist roll for aim adjustment and two-handed grips for heavier chops. The virtual axe gives the sensation of a concentrated mass at the far end; once the impact animation plays, the haptic expectation is a sudden stop and vibration through the handle, after which the user relaxes grip pressure to reset.

physicalObject: blue Pilot Vboard Master whiteboard eraser box
utilizationMethod: Grip one short end of the rectangular box so the wider mass extends outward. The rigid block creates a clear weight offset; swinging the box from the held end emulates the feel of a compact hatchet with a squarish head.

virtualObjectInfo.usage: This axe serves as a chopping tool
virtualObjectInfo.inertia: User should feel significant mass with pronounced head-heavy inertia.
virtualObjectInfo.outline: User should feel a cylindrical and substantial grip that requires a firm grasp around the handle's circumference.
virtualObjectInfo.interactionDeduction: Users adopt a full power grip: all fingers wrap around the wooden shaft, thumb closes over the index finger, and the handle rests diagonally across the palm. Interaction involves large-amplitude shoulder and elbow motion—raising the axe overhead or to the side, then accelerating it through a chopping arc generated by trunk rotation and elbow extension. The head-heavy inertia causes a pronounced lag at swing initiation and strong momentum at follow-through, which the user must dampen with wrist flexors when stopping. Secondary manipulation includes minor wrist roll for aim adjustment and two-handed grips for heavier chops. The virtual axe gives the sensation of a concentrated mass at the far end; once the impact animation plays, the haptic expectation is a sudden stop and vibration through the handle, after which the user relaxes grip pressure to reset.

physicalObject: wireless game controller with grey digital camouflage pattern
proxyLocation: lying near the upper-left quadrant of snapshot 1
utilizationMethod: Grip only the right-hand grip horn so the bulk of the controller (with its batteries inside) sits forward of your fist. This concentrates most of the mass beyond the knuckles, giving a modest head-heavy feel. Swing the wrist in short arcs; the asymmetrical weight of the controller produces a slight pendulum sensation similar to a small hammer.

virtualObjectInfo.usage: This hammer serves as a striking tool
virtualObjectInfo.inertia: User should feel significant mass concentrated in the head, creating a distinctly head-heavy sensation when wielding the hammer.
virtualObjectInfo.outline: User should feel a cylindrical and substantial grip that requires a firm grasp around the handle's circumference.
virtualObjectInfo.interactionDeduction: Users wrap a firm power grip around the cylindrical handle, often near the midpoint or slightly toward the end opposite the head. Typical motion pattern: wrist and elbow cock backward, then snap forward in a short, high-precision arc to strike a target. Because the mass is concentrated in the rectangular head, users perceive a pendulum effect—initial resistance followed by rapid acceleration. On ‘impact’ the hammer stops abruptly while the arm continues a few millimetres, creating an expected jolt that propagates back through the stiff handle. Repetitive strikes lead to a rhythmic squeeze-release pattern where grip tightens during the downswing and relaxes during the upswing.

physicalObject: matte black stainless steel water bottle with Tesla logo
proxyLocation: standing in the center-top area of snapshot 1
utilizationMethod: Hold the bottle near its bottom end, letting the filled metal body extend above your hand. The bottle’s mass is now concentrated forward, creating a clearly head-heavy inertia. The cylindrical body also provides the thick, solid grip found on a hammer handle, allowing natural cock-and-swing motions.

utilizationMethod: Hold the tube near the crimped tail end; the denser adhesive collected toward the capped tip gives a modest top-weight. The tube’s diameter matches a slim handle, so swinging from the tail provides a perceptible forward inertia during quick wrist snaps.

physicalObject: wireless game controller with grey digital camouflage pattern
utilizationMethod: Hold the controller by wrapping your fingers around ONLY the left-hand grip, letting the right grip and trigger section protrude forward. This gives you a short, thick cylindrical handle in your palm while the opposite side creates a forward extension that produces slight front-loaded inertia. Swing your forearm in small lateral arcs; the protruding half drags through the air and supplies a mild tug at the end of each stroke, approximating the sickle’s weighted blade.

virtualObjectInfo.usage: This sickle serves as a harvesting and cutting tool
virtualObjectInfo.inertia: User should feel moderate forward-weighted inertia concentrated in the curved blade, but distributed along the arc rather than at a single point.
virtualObjectInfo.outline: User should feel a cylindrical grip that requires a firm grasp around the handle's circumference.
virtualObjectInfo.interactionDeduction: Users form a secure power grip around the short, straight handle, with the blade curving forward and inward. Interaction consists of sweeping, semi-circular cutting motions: the forearm rotates inward while the wrist arcs so the blade’s inner edge hooks vegetation. Movements are generally lateral or diagonal across the body, followed by a pull toward the user’s torso. Because the curved blade distributes moderate weight along its arc, users feel forward-weighted inertia but less of a single heavy point than with an axe. During each stroke the sickle glides through resistant material; the user expects a slight drag followed by a sudden release once the cut completes, producing a brief jerk along the handle’s axis.

physicalObject: matte black stainless steel water bottle with Tesla logo
utilizationMethod: Grip the narrow neck just below the cap using a firm power grip; allow the main body of the bottle to jut forward beyond your knuckles. The smooth cylindrical neck imitates the sickle’s wooden handle while the bottle’s mass ahead of your fist provides forward-weighted inertia along its length. Now perform sweeping, inward cutting motions—the water bottle’s weight will create momentum and a noticeable follow-through similar to a real sickle stroke.

utilizationMethod: Hold one narrow end of the rectangular box like a stub handle, letting the larger flat body jut ahead of your fist. The box’s mass is concentrated beyond your grip, yielding a forward-weighted feel. Swinging it in short arcs provides a blunt yet perceptible drag followed by release, simulating the sensation of a sickle’s blade cleaving through thicker stalks.

virtualObjectInfo.usage: This sickle serves as a harvesting and cutting tool
virtualObjectInfo.inertia: User should feel moderate forward-weighted inertia concentrated in the curved blade, but distributed along the arc rather than at a single point.
virtualObjectInfo.outline: User should feel a cylindrical grip that requires a firm grasp around the handle's circumference.
virtualObjectInfo.interactionDeduction: Users form a secure power grip around the short, straight handle, with the blade curving forward and inward. Interaction consists of sweeping, semi-circular cutting motions: the forearm rotates inward while the wrist arcs so the blade’s inner edge hooks vegetation. Movements are generally lateral or diagonal across the body, followed by a pull toward the user’s torso. Because the curved blade distributes moderate weight along its arc, users feel forward-weighted inertia but less of a single heavy point than with an axe. During each stroke the sickle glides through resistant material; the user expects a slight drag followed by a sudden release once the cut completes, producing a brief jerk along the handle’s axis.
